content.title: Quick quiz
questions:
Quick quiz

Answer the three questions. There are hints to guide you to the correct answer.

When you have answered each question, click on Check my answer.

Have fun!

Question 1 of 3

We added this code to an Eyeball sprite, but the eyeball is not rotating when the mouse pointer moves.

How could you fix the problem with just one action?

  • Yes! Just adding the script does not make it run. You need to click on the green flag to make your code run.

    Your code will have a yellow outline around it when it is running.

    Forgetting to click on the green flag is a really common mistake — we all do it!

    Tip: If you change code in a loop while the script is running, Scratch will run the new code the next time that the loop runs! You don’t need to click on the green flag again. This is really useful when you are trying out ideas.

  • The script does not start with a when this sprite clicked block.

  • You do not need to run the set rotation style block lots of times. If you set it once before the loop, it will not change until you set it to a different style. Moving the set rotation style block will not help with the problem in the question.

  • You do not need to click on the Stage to get the eyeball to rotate. When the code is running, the eyeball will just follow the mouse pointer (or your finger, if you are using a tablet).

Question 2 of 3

To make the rocket interactive, the rocket sprite has this script:

when flag clicked
set rotation style [all around v]
forever
point towards (mouse-pointer v)
end

Which rocket costume should we use so that the top of the rocket will point towards the mouse pointer?

  • If the rocket is pointing to the left-hand side, the rocket will be facing the opposite direction to (away from) the mouse pointer when it rotates.

  • If the rocket is facing down, it will be facing a different direction to the mouse pointer when it rotates.

  • If the rocket is pointing to the right-hand side, the rocket is in the default position for correctly pointing towards your mouse pointer if the rotation style is set to all around.

  • If the rocket is facing up, it will be facing a different direction to the mouse pointer when it rotates.

Question 3 of 3

User interaction is how the project reacts to the user. The ‘Silly eyes’ project that you have made probably has lots of user interaction!

Which of these scripts allows user interaction after the program has started?

  • The graphic effects are cleared after the timer reaches 10. The user does not have to do anything, so there is no user interaction.

  • The sprite says “hello” after the backdrop switches. The user does not have to do anything, so there is no user interaction.

  • The user has to click on the sprite to change the colour. This is user interaction.

  • User interaction is how the project reacts to the user doing things such as moving the mouse and clicking on the screen.
